verses.text: Then I saw a new heaven and a new earth. For the first heaven and the first earth had passed away, and the sea no longer existed.
verses.comment: Echoes Isaiah's prophecy of a recreated world, emphasizing final renewal. The removal of the sea symbolizes the end of chaos and separation.

verses.text: And I saw the holy city, the new Jerusalem, coming down out of heaven from God, prepared like a bride adorned for her husband.
verses.comment: The new Jerusalem represents the dwelling place of God's people, perfected and united with Christ, the true Bridegroom.

verses.text: And I heard a loud voice from the throne saying, 'Behold, the dwelling of God is with men. He will live with them, and they will be his people, and God himself will be with them as their God.'
verses.comment: God's promise to dwell among His people finds ultimate fulfillment, reflecting the covenant language of the Old Testament. The union of God and humanity is fully realized.

verses.text: He will wipe away every tear from their eyes. Death shall be no more; neither shall there be mourning, nor crying, nor pain anymore, for the former things have passed away.
verses.comment: Isaiah prophesied the end of suffering. Here it is perfected—a physical and spiritual restoration without suffering, pointing toward eternal life.

verses.text: And he who was seated on the throne said, 'Behold, I am making all things new.' He also said, 'Write this down, for these words are trustworthy and true.'
verses.comment: God authoritatively declares the renewal of all creation. The trustworthiness of His words is confirmed directly from the throne.

verses.text: And he said to me, 'It is done! I am the Alpha and the Omega, the beginning and the end. To the thirsty I will give the spring of the water of life freely.'
verses.comment: Echoing earlier in Revelation, God declares His sovereignty as the eternal source. The living water signals spiritual sustenance, as Jesus promised in John 4.

verses.text: The one who overcomes will inherit these things, and I will be his God and he will be my son.
verses.comment: Victory through perseverance secures an intimate relationship with God, echoing both Revelation’s earlier promises and the sonship language of Psalm 2.

verses.text: But as for the cowardly, unbelieving, detestable, murderers, sexually immoral, sorcerers, idolaters, and all liars—their portion will be in the lake that burns with fire and sulfur, which is the second death.
verses.comment: A stark warning that excludes those who reject God or persist in evil; spiritual death is contrasted with life in the new creation.

verses.text: Then one of the seven angels who had the seven bowls full of the seven last plagues came and spoke to me, saying, 'Come, I will show you the bride, the wife of the Lamb.'
verses.comment: The bride image reflects the intimate union of God's faithful with Christ, first introduced in Revelation 19.

verses.text: And he carried me away in the Spirit to a great, high mountain, and showed me the holy city Jerusalem coming down out of heaven from God,
verses.comment: Prophetic visions often occur on mountains—here, the setting echoes Ezekiel’s temple vision and Isaiah’s mount of the Lord.

verses.text: having the glory of God. Its radiance was like a most rare jewel, like jasper, clear as crystal.
verses.comment: The city’s glory recalls the splendor of God's presence, as well as the precious stones of priestly garments, hinting at sanctified mediation.

verses.text: It had a great, high wall with twelve gates, and at the gates twelve angels, and names inscribed that are the names of the twelve tribes of the sons of Israel.
verses.comment: The city’s gates symbolize the fullness of God’s people from Israel, forming the foundation for the new people of God.

verses.text: On the east three gates, on the north three gates, on the south three gates, and on the west three gates.
verses.comment: The fourfold orientation shows universal accessibility to God’s dwelling—the whole world is invited into the fullness of redemption.

verses.text: And the wall of the city had twelve foundations, and on them were the twelve names of the twelve apostles of the Lamb.
verses.comment: The apostolic foundations reveal the continuity between Old and New Covenants. Christ builds on both the twelve tribes and apostles, fulfilling their roles in His kingdom.

verses.text: And the angel who spoke to me had a measuring rod of gold to measure the city, its gates, and its wall.
verses.comment: Measurement signifies both precision and perfection, reflecting God’s order in the heavenly reality, modeled after Ezekiel’s vision.

verses.text: The city was built as a square, its length the same as its width. He measured the city with his rod: twelve thousand stadia. Its length, width, and height are equal.
verses.comment: A perfect cube like the Holy of Holies in Solomon’s temple (1 Kings 6). The symbolism stresses access to God's immediate presence for all redeemed.

verses.text: He measured its wall—144 cubits by human measurement, which the angel was using.
verses.comment: The number 144 echoes the fullness of God’s people (12x12), both tribes and apostles—a unified people safeguarded in God’s presence.

verses.text: The wall was built of jasper, while the city itself was pure gold, transparent like glass.
verses.comment: Materials once reserved for priestly garments and the temple denote holiness, value, and divine glory—now manifest to all.

verses.text: The foundations of the city wall were adorned with every kind of precious stone. The first foundation was jasper; the second, sapphire; the third, chalcedony; the fourth, emerald;
verses.comment: These stones match those on the high priest’s breastplate (Exodus 28), emphasizing perpetual intercession and spiritual riches.

verses.text: the fifth, sardonyx; the sixth, sardius; the seventh, chrysolite; the eighth, beryl; the ninth, topaz; the tenth, chrysoprase; the eleventh, jacinth; the twelfth, amethyst.
verses.comment: See note above. The variety suggests the manifold grace and unity of God’s assembled people.

verses.text: And the twelve gates were twelve pearls, each gate made of a single pearl, and the streets of the city were pure gold, transparent as glass.
verses.comment: Pearls symbolize immense value and rarity; the golden streets show both luxury and purity—spiritual perfection.

verses.text: And I saw no temple in the city, for the Lord God Almighty and the Lamb are its temple.
verses.comment: God’s immediate presence replaces the temple—Christ's own body as temple (John 2:19) was a prophetic sign of this fulfilled reality.

verses.text: And the city has no need of sun or moon to shine on it, for the glory of God gives it light, and its lamp is the Lamb.
verses.comment: Jesus fulfills the prophecy as the Light of the world. God’s glory outshines created lights, indicating spiritual fullness.

verses.text: By its light the nations walk, and the kings of the earth bring their glory into it.
verses.comment: The universality of Christ’s kingdom is emphasized; all nations and rulers seek sanctification within the redeemed city.

verses.text: Its gates will never be shut by day—and there will be no night there.
verses.comment: God's continuous presence abolishes darkness and separation; eternal day symbolizes unending life and openness.

verses.text: And they will bring the glory and the honor of the nations into it.
verses.comment: Anticipates a gathered multitude from every nation, offering their perfection in worship—spiritual unity in diversity.

verses.text: But nothing unclean will ever enter it, nor anyone who does detestable or false things, but only those who are written in the Lamb’s book of life.
verses.comment: Entry is reserved for those sanctified and united to Christ. This reaffirms the necessity of spiritual purity and redemption through the Lamb.
